text:
I recently installed Apache 2.0.40 on my home PC to serve as an offline 
webserver to allow me the ability to test out my PHP and mySQL scripts without 
having to connect to the internet and upload them to a webserver.

I read the FAQ.html file that was installed with Apache and I ran the Command 
Prompt commands. Every time I try to start Apache this message is displayed:

C:\Program Files\Apache Group\Apache2\bin>apache
[Wed Sep 04 9:59:07 2002] [crit] (32538)Socket Operation on non-socket: 
make_sock: for address 192.168.0.3:80, apr_socket_opt_set: (SO_KEEPALIVE) no 
listening sockets available, shutting down.

This problem persists even if I change the PORT number or the IP address.
creator: aerith@zcentralhq.com

text:
[This is a mass bug update.]
This bug reports a problem in an older version of Apache 2.
Could you please update to the most recent version and see
if you can reproduce this problem.  If the bug still exists,
please update the bug with the latest version number.  If 
the bug no longer exists, please close the bug report.

Sorry for this impersonal response, but we get many more bug
reports than our volunteers can keep up with.
Thanks for using Apache!
creator: slive@apache.org

text:
I have the same problem with Apache 2.0.43 under Windows ME (build 4.90.3000).
The messages I get are:
[Mon Oct 28 15:39:18 2002] [crit] (730038)Socket operation on non-socket:
make_sock: for address 0.0.0.0:80, apr_socket_opt_set: (SO_KEEPALIVE)
no listening sockets available, shutting down
Unable to open logs

The output from 'apache -v' is:
Server version: Apache/2.0.43
Server built:   Oct  3 2002 05:57:04

I used to run Apache 1.3.12 on my machine but decided to upgrade the Windows
side to 2.0 to match the version I was running under Linux. I may download the
source code and see if I can get any further information about where it is dying.
creator: kevin@ve3syb.ca

text:
This is probably related to either firewall or antivirus software you
  have installed.  Such products will often modify the TCP/IP stack drivers
  so that they are no longer compatible with Apache.  Please try disabling the 
  offending software (entirely, with a restart to assure the drivers are not
  loaded) and see if you can repeat the problem.
creator: wrowe@apache.org
aerith@zcentralhq.com
text:
I have not got any Anti-Virus software or a Firewall running. I recently 
formatted my PC and tried again and the problem persists. However could it be 
due to the Intel AnyPoint Network Adapter?
Also remeber to disable IIS and/or PWS too.
creator: juan.rivera@citrix.com
kevin@ve3syb.ca
text:
I disabled both firewall and anti-virus software and was able to run Apache
2.0.43 once more. Futher tests indicate that Apache and the firewall software
(Zone Alarm version 3.1.395 by Zone Labs) were happy with each other. The
problem is the McAfee anti-virus software. They also include a firewall feature
with their anti-virus software but I had told it not to install it. It may still
be that part of their package which caused the problem.

I am getting the same error message. I am using tomcat 4.1.18 with Apache 
2.0.43, on windows XP.

Alone, the apache server runs smoothly. Even the tomcat is okay, but when I 
try to get them to work together, I get the same error message as reported at 
the point of starting the web server.  

Any other suggestions from out there?
creator: roshan@net-yan.com
don_schuerholz@yahoo.com
text:
I reproduced the very same error using Apache 2.0.44 on Windows ME.
I also installed the recommended Windows 9x patch that replaces
the libapr.dll file, before I started Apache.

creator: wrowe@apache.org
text:
Folks, this is yet another flavor of broken Win32 software.  We are afraid
  we can't do a whole lot to help you.

  Roshan Joseph ... you likely have Tomcat configured to be an HTTP (port 80)
  server as well as a backend java engine.  That's not valid.

  Learn the command  netstat -an   which shows you every port some program
  or the kernel is listening on.  You will either find a listener documented
  on port 80, or you have firewall or antivirus software installed that causes
  Apache some grief.  Or some module you installed has actually changed the
  version of the Win32 socket DLLs.  There is no way we can help with user
  configuration problems on this forum... it's strictly for tracking bugs
  within the Apache software itself.

  Final suggestion - try 2.0.45 (no special APR patch required) for a few
  new fixes to apr and httpd that might impact your success.
